title: 107_hr5090
content: The Act may be cited as the "Commission on the Accountability and Review of Federal Agencies Act". It establishes a Commission. The Commission on the Accountability and Review of Federal Agencies is established with 12 members appointed by the President. The chairperson and vice chairperson are designated by the President from among the members. Members serve for the life of the Commission, and any vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed. The Commission shall hold its first meeting at the call of the chairperson. A majority of members constitute a quorum for meetings, but a lesser number can hold hearings. The Commission's duties are outlined in Section 3. The Commission, as outlined in Section 3, evaluates agencies and programs, excluding the Department of Defense, to recommend realignment or elimination. It submits a plan to Congress with proposed legislation based on specific criteria. The Commission evaluates agencies and programs for realignment or elimination based on specific criteria such as duplicative functions, wasteful spending, mismanagement, and outdated purposes. The Commission evaluates agencies and programs for realignment or elimination based on specific criteria such as duplicative functions, wasteful spending, mismanagement, and outdated purposes. The Commission shall submit a report to the President and Congress within 2 years of enactment of the Act, including a plan with supporting documentation and proposed legislation. Funds saved from the plan's implementation will be used to support other domestic programs. The proposed legislation also addresses the relocation of federal employees. The legislation requires agencies to relocate employees if their positions are eliminated due to a realignment or elimination plan. The legislation grants powers to the Commission. The Commission, subcommittees, or members may hold hearings, take testimony, and require witnesses and evidence. Subpoenas can be issued to compel attendance and production of materials. The Commission can issue subpoenas signed by the chairperson for testimony or evidence. Failure to comply may result in a court order for appearance or production of documents, punishable as contempt. The Commission can also obtain information directly from Federal agencies. The Commission can request necessary information from Federal agencies and use the United States mails. They are also allowed to accept gifts or donations. SEC. 5. COMMISSION PERSONNEL MATTERS. Members of the Commission are compensated differently based on their federal status. Non-federal members do not receive compensation, while federal officers or employees serve without additional pay. Travel expenses are allowed for Commission members at authorized rates. The chairperson has the authority to appoint staff for the Commission. The chairperson of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and additional personnel without following civil service laws. The executive director can determine their own compensation, not exceeding the maximum rate for a GS-15 position. The executive director and Commission personnel are federal employees under title 5, United States Code. Members of the Commission are not included. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. Temporary and intermittent services can be procured. The chairperson of the Commission may procure temporary and intermittent services under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code, at rates for individuals which do not exceed the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay prescribed for level V of the Executive Schedule under section 5316 of such title. The Commission will terminate 90 days after submitting the report under section 3(d). Congressional consideration of reform proposals will follow. In this section, an implementation bill is defined as a bill introduced without modification containing proposed legislation from a report submitted to Congress. A calendar day is defined as a day when either House is not in session due to an adjournment of more than 3 days. On the first day both Houses are in session following the report submission, a single implementation bill must be introduced in the Senate by the Majority Leader. The implementation bills introduced in the Senate by the Majority Leader and designated Members, and in the House of Representatives by the Speaker and designated Members, shall be referred to appropriate committees for consideration. The House of Representatives committee may report an implementation bill without amendment. If the committee fails to report the bill within 15 days, it will be discharged and placed on the calendar for floor consideration. The motion to proceed to the consideration of the implementation bill is highly privileged in the House of Representatives and privileged in the Senate. It is not debatable, subject to amendment, or reconsideration. If agreed to, the implementation bill becomes the unfinished business. The implementation bill is the unfinished business of the House until disposed of. It cannot be amended in the Senate or the House of Representatives. Debate is limited to 10 hours, with equal time for those in favor and those opposing. Further debate limitations and certain motions are not allowed. A vote on final passage follows immediately. The implementation bill is the unfinished business of the House until disposed of. Debate is limited to 10 hours, with equal time for those in favor and those opposing. Appeals from the decisions of the Chair relating to the application of the rules shall be decided without debate. Coordination with the other House's implementation bill follows specific procedures. The implementation bill of the other House shall not be referred to a committee. The procedure for the House receiving the bill remains the same, but the final vote will be on the other House's bill. This section is enacted by Congress as part of the rules of each House for the procedure to be followed. The implementation bill described in subsection (a) must follow specific procedures in the House, superseding other rules if inconsistent. Each House has the constitutional right to change its rules regarding procedures at any time. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2002 through 2005 is provided for carrying out this Act.
